properties.Name: Asset
properties.Description:
An economic resource that is expected to provide benefits to the business organization.    Anything having commercial or exchange value that is owned by a business, institution, or individual.   

Property used in the conduct of a trade or business, such as business machinery and office furniture. 

Assets have three primary characteristics:

(1)  The asset will provide anticipated or probable future benefits

(2)  The business organization controls the asset

(3)  The asset results from a prior event or financial transaction

Assets are normally divided into 4 categories:

1 - CURRENT ASSETS
2 - INVESTMENTS
3 - PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT
4 - INTANGIBLE ASSETS

Assets are expressed in money or are convertible into money and may include deferred charges that are not resources, such as deferred costs.

Assets can be recognized and measured in conformity with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP).

An Asset may be tangible or intangible.

Tangible Assets have physical substance.

Intangible Assets lack physical substance and result from a right granted by the government or another company such as goodwill or a patent.

An asset may be current or noncurrent.

Current assets have a life of one year or less.
Noncurrent assets have a life in excess of one year.

Columns.Name: AssetId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset.

Columns.Name: AssetName
Columns.Description: The name of the Asset.

Columns.Name: AssetDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Asset.

Columns.Name: AssetNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Asset.

Columns.Name: AssetModelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Model.

Columns.Name: ManufacturerSerialNumber
Columns.Description: The manufacturer's serial number of the Asset.

Columns.Name: OrganizationAssignedSerialNumber
Columns.Description: The serial number assigned to the Asset by the organization holding it.

Columns.Name: ElectronicSerialNumber
Columns.Description: The electronic serial number is a unique identification number embedded by manufacturers on a microchip in their product. While the ESN was first commonly used in wireless phones it has found traction in other electronic products.

Columns.Name: GlobalIndividualAssetIdentifier
Columns.Description: The Global Individual Asset Identifier (GIAI) is a simple tool used to identify an asset by type, uniquely where required. The GIAI is part of the GS1 system of standards.

Columns.Name: GlobalReturnableAssetIdentifier
Columns.Description:
The Global Returnable Asset Identifier (GRAI) was developed by GS1 to be used to identify assets by type. It can also be used to uniquely identify assets by including the serial number. 

The GRAI is used to identify Returnable Transport Items (RTI) such as pallets, roll container, crates. The GRAI identifies the type of returnable asset.

Columns.Name: AssetManufacturedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Asset was manufactured.

Columns.Name: AssetPurchasedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Asset was purchased.

Columns.Name: AssetDeliveredDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Asset was delivered.

Columns.Name: AssetPlacedInServiceDate
Columns.Description:
Placed in service. Strictly a tax term. You can only start depreciating property (or take a Sec. 179 expense election) when the property is 'placed in service.' 

That means when the property is available for use in its assigned function. For example, you purchase a machine and it's not delivered until 1997. Even though you may have paid for the machine in 1996, you can't begin depreciation until 1997. 

Similarly, if the machine is delivered in 1996, but the technicians didn't arrive to install and test the machine until 1997, you can't begin depreciation until 1997.

Columns.Name: RetirementDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Asset was removed from operative service with the associated adjustments to the depreciation accounts.

Columns.Name: FreightInCostAmount
Columns.Description:
The cost to deliver an asset.

This amount usually used to calculate the Actual Cost Amount, which includes freight-in and installation costs but not interest on debt to acquire it.

Columns.Name: InstallationCostAmount
Columns.Description:
The cost to install an asset.

This amount usually used to calculate the Actual Cost Amount, which includes freight-in and installation costs but not interest on debt to acquire it.

Columns.Name: AcquisitionCostAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount paid for an asset.

This amount usually includes freight-in and installation costs but not interest on debt to acquire it.

Columns.Name: BookCostAmount
Columns.Description: The cost at the time an asset is purchased or realized, i.e. the total amount paid to acquire an asset.

Columns.Name: AdjustedCostBasisAmount
Columns.Description:
The value that is the starting point for calculating the gain or loss (depreciation, depletion or amortization) of the asset.

It is the cost of the asset offset by specific adjustments for modifications to the fixed asset such as capital improvements.

Columns.Name: AssetDepreciableBasisAmount
Columns.Description: The amount upon which depreciation is calculated. This amount is calculated based on Acquired Value, Freight, Installation Costs, Salvage Value and other amounts.

Columns.Name: EconomicLifeMonths
Columns.Description:
The estimated period expressed in months that a fixed asset will provide benefits to the business organization.

This is usually less than the physical life of an asset because an asset continues to have physical life despite obsolescence.

Columns.Name: DepreciableLifeMonths
Columns.Description:
The economic or physical life of a fixed asset expressed in months.

All fixed assets except land are depreciated over the number of years of expected use.

Columns.Name: PhysicalLifeMonths
Columns.Description:
The length of time that the fixed asset should be operational expressed in months.

This is different from the economic or depreciation life of the asset, which have to do with the accounting value to the business and not the actual length of time that the fixed asset may operate or be capable of operation.

Columns.Name: ServiceLifeMonths
Columns.Description:
The time that an asset will provide benefits to the business organization expressed in months.

The depreciation expense determination requires an estimated number of years of usefulness.

The service life may be less than its physical life due to obsolescence.

Columns.Name: AssetEmissionFactorUnits
Columns.Description: The asset emission factor units.

Columns.Name: AssetEmissionFactorUomId
Columns.Description: The asset type emission factor UOM.

Columns.Name: SubjectToGovernmentPollutionRequirementsIndicator
Columns.Description: A flag or indicator denoting that the Asset is subject to US government pollution requirements.

Columns.Name: LongLivedAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: LONG-LIVED ASSETS are usually those assets that are not consumed during the normal course of business, e.g. land, buildings and equipment, etc.

Columns.Name: MonitoredExpenseAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: These are fixed assets with a useful life of one year or more and designated by authorized personnel as "theft sensitive".

Columns.Name: RealPropertyAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: Real Assets can be defined as fixed assets of a long-term nature that are held or used beyond one year, such as land, buildings, machinery and certain types of fixtures.

Columns.Name: UnmonitoredAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: These are assets (group assets such as furniture, and tables) with an original cost of less than typically $5000, including ancillary cost, with a useful life of one year or more. They are not tracked/   These are typically referred to as group assets and include items such as furniture, office equipment, tables, chairs, etc.

Columns.Name: CapitalEquipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: An article of property that is not permanently attached to buildings or grounds and has an acquisition cost of $5,000 or more and a life expectancy of one year or more.   Allowable acquisition costs include shipping and installation fees and all costs related to the importation of equipment from foreign countries.

Columns.Name: ExpendableAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: An asset with a useful life of more than one year that does not meet the threshold for a capital asset ($5,000).

Columns.Name: MinorEquipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Property meeting the equipment definition except that it has a unit value of less than $5,000 aka "non-capital equipment."

Columns.Name: EncumberedAssetIndicator
Columns.Description: ENCUMBERED is when an asset is owned by one party subject to the legal claims of another party. One example is a homeowner that owns a home that is subject to (encumbered by) the claims of the mortgage holder.

Columns.Name: CapitalAssetIndicator
Columns.Description:
This is a fixed asset with an original total cost of $5000 or greater, including applicable ancillary costs and with a useful life of one year or more. 
It will be capitalized for financial accounting purposes.

Columns.Name: AssetTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Type.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: LedgerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger Account.

Columns.Name: WarrantyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warranty.

Columns.Name: AssetAccountingCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Accounting Category.

Columns.Name: BarCodeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bar Code.

Columns.Name: VendorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Vendor.

Columns.Name: RfidTagId
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier of a RFID Tag.

The transmitter/receiver pair or transceiver plus the information storage mechanism attached to the object is referred to as the tag, transponder, electronic label, code plate and various other terms. 

Although transponder is technically the most accurate, the most common term and the one preferred by the Automatic Identification Manufacturers is tag.

Columns.Name: OrderId
Columns.Description: The unique number that identifies an Order.

Columns.Name: AssetCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Category.

Columns.Name: AssetClassId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Class.

Columns.Name: MaintenancePeriodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Maintenance Period.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: AssetTitleStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Asset Title Status.

Properties.Description:
An economic resource that is expected to provide benefits to the business organization.    Anything having commercial or exchange value that is owned by a business, institution, or individual.   

Property used in the conduct of a trade or business, such as business machinery and office furniture. 

Assets have three primary characteristics:

(1)  The asset will provide anticipated or probable future benefits

(2)  The business organization controls the asset

(3)  The asset results from a prior event or financial transaction

Assets are normally divided into 4 categories:

1 - CURRENT ASSETS
2 - INVESTMENTS
3 - PROPERTY, PLANT AND EQUIPMENT
4 - INTANGIBLE ASSETS

Assets are expressed in money or are convertible into money and may include deferred charges that are not resources, such as deferred costs.

Assets can be recognized and measured in conformity with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP).

An Asset may be tangible or intangible.

Tangible Assets have physical substance.

Intangible Assets lack physical substance and result from a right granted by the government or another company such as goodwill or a patent.

An asset may be current or noncurrent.

Current assets have a life of one year or less.
Noncurrent assets have a life in excess of one year.
